newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Central European grain exports seen rising.
newsitem.headline: Central European grain exports seen rising.

text.p: Increasing grain production will lead to higher exportable surpluses in central European countries which have applied to join the European Union, an agricultural conference was told on Wednesday.

Grain production of the six applicant countries could climb to 92 million tonnes by the year 2005 and consumption would reach 85 million tonnes leaving an exportable surplus of about seven million tonnes, Klaus Schumacher of Hamburg-based Toepfer International told an Agra Europe conference.

Forecasting the grain market in the six central European states by 20005, he suggested cereals acreage would increase by one percent per year and yields by 1.8 percent to 3.8 tonnes per hectare compared with an EU average of 5.0 tonnes per hectare.
"What is more uncertain is the forecast of the increase in consumption of 2.5 per cent a year reflecting a forecast growth in population by 0.7 percent and increasing incomes," he said.
Of the total forecast surplus he said that approximately five million tonnes would be wheat and the remaining two million tonnes corn and barley.

With a consumption increase of only two per cent a year instead of 2.5 percent the six countries export surplus would increase to about 11 million tonnes, whereas a strong growth in domestic consumption of three percent a year would leave only approximately four million tonnes for export.

Although grain exports from the six central European countries will increase the growth is likely to be less dramatic than expected by many analysts but, changes to the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) seem necessary to avoid dramatically rising EU grain surpluses, he added.
